This game is filled with fast-paced movement and fighting, with non-stop obstacles and challenges throughout the entire game. I love the movement-based combat, the weapons, and the story is so well told in real-time that it draws you in with nearly every action you take. The scientists also make me chuckle thanks to the memes.

I played this game blind on Twitch, and there was never a dull moment during this whole experience. I will always recommend this game.

(To simplify this review, funni orange man go boing boing with bald scientist and there's a lot of aliens and military who go bang bang shooty pow).

The gameplay is great, ducking behind cover, waiting for cues and thinking how you would in real life is amazing. The maps on the other hand can be pretty good, but cryptic or just infuriating (I don't want to talk about how many times I had to look up a guide) and the game is just non-sensical, there's a fan that looks like it would chop you up (like every other fan up to that point) that blows you into the air as well as a smaller fan that does the same, despite being smaller than every other fan in the game (most others chop you up)

Absolute classic! Coming from someone who has never played a single Half-Life game, I can see why this series really took off. My only gripe is the platforming aspects; other than that, the game is fantastic!
A classic hit still relevant almost 25 years after its original release.

Pros:
+++ There are very few games that I've enjoyed as much as this one. The first Half-Life is truly a masterpiece.

Cons:
---- I didn't get to see Gordon's fat juicy ass. To be honest my day was ruined.
this game is as fun as beating the shit out of a Vortigaunt with a crowbar.

Half-Life is a great game, I can tell you that for sure. This game was just what I needed for my small game collection, already had FPS, already had racing games, already had puzzle games, already had MMORPGs, so I thought I'd add a game with a heavy emphasis on story, and Half-Life ended up being that game.

This was far from what I expected, I expected some boring FPS like any other (specially since this game was old) but I ended up experiencing something that could have released today and I wouldn't even notice.

I recommend you try this game out, it's awesome.

[Now I'm gonna start playing the sequel, hope it's as good if not even better]

Had to buy this version when I wanted to replay it again because apparently the Source version got destroyed by platform updates like 8 years ago and Valve never fixed it. It's still a solid game, though.

Magistrale, sublime e appassionante survival horror che dopo oltre 20 anni dalla pubblicazione fa ancora la sua bella figura nel mondo fps in generale. Proiettatevi un momento nel 1998-1999 e mentre vengono i vari rilasciati Resident Evil 2, Fifa 99 o Unreal, Valve decide di pubblicare il suo primo videogioco. Giocatelo e capirete il motivo per cui l'hype di tale gioco è ancora alle stelle. Vale la pena acquistarlo a prezzo pieno, figuratevi a nemmeno 2 euro.

A compelling and curious story. Absolutely would play again. There are some very, very minor bugs where I would get stuck in a wall and have to reload my last quicksave but most of the time that was of my own dumb doings.
Bastante bueno para empezar a speedrunear, aun no me lo termino pero esta buenazo.

쇠지렛대의 전설이 시작된 곳. 또한 모 더빙의 전설이 여기서 시작되었다.

너무 고전적인 느낌이 강해서 같은 회사의 Left 4 Dead 만큼 즐기지는 못했다.

그냥 스토리는 유튜브로 감상하고 후속작들을 플레이하는 편이 좋았을 지도 모르겠다.

The embodiment of "run. think. shoot. live"... atleast in the beginning.

I played and finished the game on hard mode over the course of a week, and overall I'd say I enjoyed the game a lot, But man, it really starts dragging during the last few chapters of the game.
Also know that I intentionally avoided all media about the series as a whole outside of a few ads made for the games and the unintentional occasional nugget of info; so my slate is as clean as possible for such an old and well-perceived series.

So... at the start of the game, I was immediately engrossed from the first "cutscene". I put quotes around that since it's really more "showing off" while simultaneously giving you an idea of where you are and how advanced the technology is, as well as you can move during it (which I didn't know until accidentally hitting a movement key). I like it. But afterwards, it did take a long time to start get through story stuff and get to the action. The first weapon you get, the crowbar, felt very powerful. It swings fast and I used it to kill a guard early before he could shoot me back, which I then I got a gun for. But when past that, the crowbar took way too long to do any meaningful damage, or they are headcrabs... and the crowbar does not work well on headcrabs.

But most of the other weapons feel pretty good. I don't like how the crossbow feels so stiff to use, but it's super powerful and silent, so I forgive it. You move pretty fast in this game too, which I first thought would be counter-productive to the game's seemingly slow pace. But after a short while, I grew to appreciate it. I also like the puzzle-combat style of the game (is that even a style? idk I kinda made that up just now). You can use a variety of weapons and strategies for almost every situation, some better than others of course. It reminds me of Metal Gear a lot, and I really like Metal Gear.

I was having a lot of fun going through the game, using minimal saves and only dying a few times (except that really hard invisible agent fight. That had a lot of dying before I sat back and outsmarted them). And I then I got to the rocket. I honestly felt like that was the end of the game for a while. It felt like I accomplished the main goal (stop the aliens from teleporting in) and you got to the surface. I though the game was broken when the credits didn't show up, and I didn't find an obvious way to progress. So, with a lot of hesitation, looked it up. You had to backtrack a bit to continue. Fine, ok. Not too big of an issue and it doesn't happen a lot in the game before nor since.

But after the rocket, the game started to drag. Right afterwards is a water section, which I hate (esp because I get motion sick super easily). And this was also the start of some bullshit enemy teleporting. You are on a narrow walkway that is slippery, causing hard to control sliding. The pool of water below has a tanky, very hard to deal with, pretty fast (also scary) alien fish thing that eats your legs in less than 3 chomps. You have to jump across the gap while sliding on the puddle. You start running across the water, ready to jump, then an alien spawns behind you, zaps you, and since i was at low health, dies. That was pretty frustrating, but no huge deal. But this kept happening. Not very often, but enough and at the most annoying moments, causing it to be frustrating.

And not too long after that chapter, the game introduces these bulky armored aliens that have a "bee" gun. They shoot homing bees that hurt pretty badly considering they shoot out of the bee gun pretty quickly. These destroy the "run, think, shoot, live" slogan to "run, see bee, shoot, die, reload save, use boring strat, live". You can't tell when these guys show up, so when you walk into a room to assess the situation and plan an attack / escape and one of these guys notices a slight disturbance in the force, they turn around and shoot you with 8 homing bees which usually cripple you down to 30 or lower health. You can counter them effectively when you get your own bee gun, but you need a lot of bees to kill one, they come out slower, and their homing capabilities are severely neutered. You have to shoot them within what feels like a couple of feet of them for them to home onto. This leads to a lot of long sessions of hiding behind a wall, poking the armored alien with bees, hoping he doesn't walk too much (which either lets him see and shoot you, or makes your bee-poking angle not viable), and sitting there for upwards of 20 seconds to finally play the game normally again. They only start showing up more and more, killing the strategy element of the game for me. Atleast the bee gun has unlimited ammo, which is nice since you run low on ammo occasionally (and melee isn't much of an option).

I feel like the bee gun and the shitty "teleports behind you" enemies really start getting annoying when you reach the reactor... which doesn't help since the reactor is more "go here and press button" than most other puzzles, especially since the puzzling was replaced with combat. And the combat usually has 2 or 3 bee guys, and I hate bee guys since they kill the game's pace and encourages a dumb cheese strat.

But the levels were what kept me playing. They either have great puzzles (my favorites being On a Rail and the Invisible ninja fights) or have breathtaking atmosphere (the Xen planet and the areas during Surface Tension for instance). Even the reactor level looked nice and felt like it made sense, on top of a really good teleport sections.

There are a fair share of annoying bugs though (mouse settings resetting and constantly getting stuck on those flying enemies and inside pipes mainly), but being an old game, I can forgive it for a few bugs here and there. I think It's worth playing game due to it's legacy on it's own; but if you want to play this game purely for it's own merits, I'd still think it'll be a fun ride. If I wanted to be stubborn, I'd stay stop after you launch the rocket. But you will be missing out on some of the best levels if you stop at what I think would've been a great stopping point. Plus maybe the bee guys are not nearly as much of an issue on easier difficulties.

6/10, really great game, and I'm looking forward to the famously incredible sequel. If it weren't for bee guys, it's be more of a 8/10; yes, I hate them that much. They kill pacing, are a pain to deal with more than 1 of at a time (which is almost always the case), and probably single handedly the reason for 75% of my saves and deaths.
